author: Jeff Porter
title: I-Team
text: Weather Alert Day! Morning snow showers, windy and turning much colder by late afternoon with heavy lake effect snow by tonight; Jeff updates LIVE 4:30 to 9:00 a.m. Today: Snow showers in the morning with light accumulation possible. Becoming windy and turning much colder late in the day. High in the lower 30s. Wind W 15-25 mph with gusts to 35 mph. Tonight: Snow showers, heavy at times, frigid, and windy. Accumulations: 1\" to 3\". Icy roads, and very difficult traveling. Lows in the middle teens with below zero wind chills. W 15-30 mph with higher gusts with 40 mph gusts. Tomorrow: Snow showers, especially in the morning, frigid, and windy. Accumulations: up to 1-2\". Snow quickly diminishing in the afternoon. High in the middle to upper teens. Wind W 15-25 mph. Tomorrow Night: Mainly cloudy, cold. Low in the lower to middle teens. Wind SW 5 mph. Friday: Variably cloudy, occasional sunshine possible. Not as cold. High in the upper 20s. Wind SE 5-10 mph. Saturday: Morning wet snow, perhaps some freezing rain, turns to all rain from south to north. Light slushy accumulation possible in the morning. Breezy and much warmer. High in the upper 30s. Wind SE 15-25 mph. Sunday: Cloudy with a chilly rain from time to time. High in the lower 40s. Wind shifts from SE to SW 10 mph. You can always connect with the Weather Alert Network Team on Facebook ( Keith Thompson , Jeff Porter , Will Haenni , Collin Rogers ), X ( @weathermankeith , @jeffporterwx , @ WillWWMT , @Collin_wwmt ), and Instagram ( @weathermankeith , @jeffporterwx , @WillWWMT ). Good morning, West Michigan! Today is a WEATHER ALERT DAY, one of two back-to-back. Though we'll see areas of snow this morning and early afternoon, the impactful weather for this alert day won't arrive in full force until late in the afternoon. A cold front will arrive around sunset triggering snow showers. Behind the front, the coldest air we've had since last January plows into West Michigan, triggering numerous lake effect snow showers in west to east oriented snow bands. The snow will likely be heavy at times through Thursday morning, when a shift in the wind will quickly shut down the snow bands. But before that happens, some parts of West Michigan, especially in the snow belt west of US 131, may see up to 10\" of snow. Add to that a sometimes-gusty west wind, and you have a recipe for hazardous driving with icy, snow-covered roads, and periods of reduced visibility. Occasional whiteouts are possible. The snow ends quickly Thursday, diminishing by early afternoon thanks to a shift in the wind. Our best chance for sunshine -- and it isn't great -- is Friday as temperatures start to warm. A wintry mix in the morning is how we begin Saturday with freezing rain possibly playing a part. Temps warm to the upper 30s Saturday and lower 40s Sunday, both afternoon's having a chance for rain. Meteorologist Jeff Porter updates the outlook LIVE this morning on News Channel 3. Catch his LIVE reports from 4:30 to 9:00. Have a wonderful Wednesday! ","forecast":
